resources.string: Click to open/close the navigation menu.
The navigation menu contains an assortment of buttons used to navigate within the app. Instructions for the usage of each navigation button are provided on the proceeding help pages.
The navigation menu contains an assortment of buttons used to navigate within the app.
*IMPORTANT* Read the help pages before first use. Click the purple button to access the help pages. Instructions for the usage of each navigation button are provided on the help pages.
After installing the Budometer app you will need to take some pictures of the buds you want to analyze.
Budometer requires that photographs be taken from a close-up vantage point and in the manner described below.
Click the camera icon in the navigation menu to start the camera.
(2) Position the camera close to the bud as indicated by the red outline.
It\'s important that the photo contains bud only without background showing around the edges.
(4) Click the large center button to capture the image.
(5) Click to change the camera\'s flash setting.
(3) Toggles between the front-facing and rear-facing cameras.
The captured image will be displayed on the camera\'s image preview page.
Saved images are saved to the folder labeled \'Budometer\' located inside the \'Pictures\' directory.
(7) Click to discard the current image and take a new photo.
Images captured using the camera are accessible through the image gallery.
To run an analysis start by selecting four images from the gallery.
Click the gallery menu button to open the gallery folder page.
To access images in a specific folder tap the folder icon.
Select four images then click the green \'pie chart\' menu button to begin analyzing.
Analysis of the images will take a few seconds before the results are displayed.

Information resulting from the completion of analysis is displayed for the user and conveys a variety of facts about the plants in the analyzed photographs. The diagrams below describe the results interface and the information displayed.
(1) Shows the four images used in this analysis.
(2) A pie chart displaying all colors and shades extracted from the images.
(3) Values indicating what percentage of the image each specific color shade represents.
(4) A color bar that displays values indicating what percentage of the image each group of color shades represents.
For example, all shades of purple combined make up 3.9% of the image color.
(5) Close button, when clicked exits the results page.
(6) Save button, when clicked saves the current analysis results for later viewing.
(7) Text indicating if plants are ready to harvest or if they are still growing as determined by machine learning algorithms.
This information is automatically displayed by the software at the conclusion of an analysis.
(8) Text indicating the percentage of pistils that have turned orange/brown, wilted, and curled.
(10) Text showing the strain of cannabis represented in the analyzed photos.
This information is user input, entering the cannabis strain is optional.
(9) Crop id, archived analysis readings are grouped according to the crop or plant from which they were taken and therefore each reading must have a crop/plant identifier.
This information is user input, entering the crop id is required to save the reading.
(11) Text stating the date that the analysis was performed.
This information is automatically displayed by the software at the conclusion of an analysis.
(12) A text view that allows users to enter notes for later reference.
Budometer\'s image cropping tool can be used to trim off unwanted background colors along the image edges.
Select the folder containing the image.
Click expanding menu button to reveal the navigation menu.
Clicking the yellow crop image button opens the selected image in the image cropping tool.
Resize and reposition the cropping guide(1) so that the section of image inside the guide represents the image that you would like to keep.
Clicking the crop image button(2) crops the image, saves the edited version to the gallery, refreshes the gallery, and exits the cropping tool.
The close button(3) exits image cropping.

Archived analysis readings are grouped according to the crop or plant from which they were taken. Each reading includes all information and user input from the original analysis and displays it in an organized and easy to navigate user interface.
All archived readings for a single crop or plant are displayed in a list that scrolls vertically as shown by the image labeled \'Plant/Crop Readings\'.
(1) List header, the first entry in every collection of previous reading is a header.
(6) Close button, when clicked exits the results page.
The list header displays the crop id for the specific crop from which the readings were taken.
The strain of cannabis grown in that crop.
The date the analysis was performed.
Scroll horizontally to navigate through multiple groupings each containing all of the readings for a previous crop or plant.
(2)Individual readings, all list elements below the list header represents individual readings.
Click on a list element to display the details of that specific reading.
Clicking a list element displays the information for the archived reading stated on the list element.
The information is displayed as shown in the images labeled \'Chart\' and \'Saved Input\'.
(5) Delete button, when clicked it permanently deletes that specific archived reading and all associated images.
(7) All information is displayed for the particular archived analysis.

Budometer takes the guesswork out of determining the optimal point at which to harvest your crop. Using revolutionary machine learning algorithms Budometer evaluates numerous factors such as bud density, pistil coloration, pistil curling, trichome coloration, and leaf discoloration to determine the point of peak bud maturity. Below is a brief explanation of how each of these factors is used in the determination of bud maturity.

Cannabis flowers grow as clusters of calyxes developing at leaf nodes along the branches. As the buds mature they become larger and denser filling in space between them. Budometer\'s machine learning algorithms very precisely evaluate and compare changes in that spacing to determine increases in bud density.

When the majority of the pistils on your plants are white and robust, it is far too early to harvest, and you probably have to wait several more weeks. Peak maturity and the prime point to harvest is when 50% to 70% of the pistils have turned an orange/brown color and have begun to curl. Budometer analyzes, tracks, and graphs pistil coloration allowing you to monitor precise changes as your buds develop.

During the early stages of flowering buds are covered in bright white, robust pistils. As the plants approach peak maturity, their pistils begin wilting and curling inward as they change to an orange/brown color. Curling starts at the tips and progresses until the pistil has withered entirely and changed color completely. Budometer recognizes and incorporates the degree pistil curling when assessing a plants stage of maturity.

Trichomes are sticky resin-bearing glands that cover buds as they mature. Developing trichomes go through three consecutive color states beginning clear then turning cloudy and finishing amber. The best time to harvest your cannabis is when 30% of the trichomes are amber, and 70% are clear or cloudy. Trichome coloration is another factor Budometer uses when evaluating bud maturity.

Another indicator of cannabis maturity thatâ€™s examined by Budometer can be seen in the leaves surrounding the calyxes and even the larger fan leaves. When the plant is ripe, the leaves will turn yellowish, start curling up and becoming dark and brittle. This drying and curling of the leaves occurs because cannabis consumes less water as it nears its final phase of life.
A crop id is required when saving analysis results.
